abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Water Supply
            Project for Cote d'Ivoire was satisfactory. The project
            achieved or exceeded most of it objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was moderate, sustainability is
            uncertain, and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower
            was satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, the association of a SECAL operation and an
            ongoing investment operation is a practical alternative to a
            hybrid loan. Second, centralized maintenance of scattered
            rural facilities is not sustainable, even if it is carried
            out by a private company. Third, a technical department of
            the central government that is deprived of financial
            incentives and accountability should not be expected manage
            and make responsible investment decisions. Finally, projects
            that aim at developing the connection ratio and water
            services to the urban poor should systematically measure the
            actual willingness to pay of low-income domestic users and
            take into account the consumers' surplus.
